prior_works.title: Multi-Task Learning as Multi-Objective Optimization
prior_works.role: Foundational multi-task optimization (MGDA) that combines task gradients to approach Pareto-optimal updates for shared parameters.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: E2E-MFD’s gradient-matrix strategy for shared parameters echoes MGDA’s principle of jointly optimizing multiple objectives to avoid suboptimal solutions caused by task conflicts.

prior_works.title: GradNorm: Gradient Normalization for Adaptive Loss Balancing in Deep Multitask Networks
prior_works.authors: Zhao Chen, Vijay Badrinarayanan, Chen-Yu Lee, Andrew Rabinovich
prior_works.role: Adaptive balancing of multi-task learning dynamics via gradient magnitudes.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The need to balance learning between fusion quality and detection accuracy in E2E-MFD is directly informed by GradNorm’s idea of regulating task contributions through gradient-based signals.

prior_works.title: PCGrad: Gradient Surgery for Multi-Task Learning
prior_works.role: Conflict-avoidant gradient projection to mitigate negative interference across tasks.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: E2E-MFD’s comprehensive optimization in the gradient matrix aligns with PCGrad’s strategy of modifying gradients to reduce inter-task conflicts during synchronous joint optimization.

prior_works.title: U2Fusion: A Unified Unsupervised Image Fusion Network
prior_works.role: Strong unsupervised IR-VIS image fusion baseline emphasizing universal, task-agnostic fusion.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: E2E-MFD builds on U2Fusion-like unsupervised fusion but departs from the decoupled paradigm by jointly optimizing fusion with detection to maximize downstream performance.

prior_works.title: DenseFuse: A Fusion Approach to Infrared and Visible Images
prior_works.role: Early CNN-based IR-VIS fusion method emphasizing structural and detail preservation.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: E2E-MFD inherits the representation-learning perspective of DenseFuse but replaces standalone fusion training with an end-to-end pipeline that synchronizes fusion and detection objectives.

prior_works.title: DETR: End-to-End Object Detection with Transformers
prior_works.authors: Nicolas Carion, Francisco Massa, Gabriel Synnaeve, Nicolas Usunier, Alexander Kirillov, Sergey Zagoruyko
prior_works.role: Introduced fully end-to-end object detection via set prediction and bipartite matching.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: E2E-MFD’s commitment to a single-phase, end-to-end training regime for detection is conceptually aligned with DETR’s elimination of multi-stage heuristics, facilitating synchronous optimization with fusion.

prior_works.title: Illumination-Aware Faster R-CNN for Robust Multispectral Pedestrian Detection
prior_works.role: Representative multispectral (RGB–thermal) detection framework with modality-aware fusion for robustness.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: By revealing the gains and limitations of feature-level fusion for multispectral detection, this work motivates E2E-MFD’s tighter, joint optimization of low-level fusion and high-level detection to avoid suboptimal stagewise solutions.

synthesis_narrative:
E2E-MFD’s key contribution—an end-to-end, synchronous optimization framework that jointly learns multimodal image fusion and object detection while explicitly managing gradient interactions—emerges at the confluence of task-agnostic fusion networks, end-to-end detection, and multi-task optimization theory. Classical IR–VIS fusion methods such as DenseFuse and U2Fusion established that learnable fusion can preserve structure and detail, but they typically train fusion models independently of downstream tasks. In parallel, end-to-end detectors like DETR demonstrated the benefits of single-phase training that removes hand-crafted stages and post-processing. E2E-MFD unifies these directions by integrating the fusion module directly with the detection head in a single training loop, ensuring the fused representation is shaped by detection objectives.
Critically, the paper addresses a central obstacle in joint training: conflicting gradients for shared parameters across objectives (fusion quality vs. detection accuracy). Foundational multi-task learning works—MGDA’s Pareto-based gradient composition, GradNorm’s adaptive balancing via gradient magnitudes, and PCGrad’s conflict-aware gradient surgery—directly inform E2E-MFD’s comprehensive gradient-matrix strategy. By adopting the principle of coordinating gradients to mitigate interference, E2E-MFD avoids the suboptimal minima common in stagewise or naively joint setups. Finally, insights from multispectral detection (e.g., illumination-aware Faster R-CNN) underscore the value of modality fusion for robust perception, while highlighting limitations of decoupled pipelines—limitations E2E-MFD overcomes through synchronous, end-to-end optimization that boosts both fusion quality and detection mAP.
